title: What violin pieces have a relatively easy piano accompaniment? - Quora

response.answer_text: It all depends on what you regard as easy.. Most Mozart sonatas, especially those in two movements (except the late ones), and the Schubert sonatinas are relatively easy. I’m sure there is a lot of other stuff out there, though. Most of it will be rather low quality stuff by second-rate composers and/or arrangements… Also, the Dvorak sonatina is delightful though a tad more difficult. Bartok’s Romanian Dances also come to mind… Most of Haydn’s piano trios can safely be played without the cello (which simply duplicates the piano’s bass notes). There is a lot of great music here, though of varying difficulty…

many famous violin solos have a fairly straightforward piano accompaniment which can be simplified even further if necessary - for example the Meditation from Thais by Massanet, or the Intermezzo from Cavaleria Rusticana by Mascagni. Even the famous Czardas by Monti is not hard for a pianist, and easiest of all might be something like the Haydn Serenade (though the purists will all immediately recognize that its attribution to Haydn is mistaken - it was discovered to be by the relatively obscure Ramon Hofstetter). Once you get into real repertoire, especially sonatas, then the piano parts are usually more difficult than the violin parts.
